title: letter Quality Education
summary: Philosophical letter defining quality education through UNICEF criteria (healthy learners, safe environments, relevant content, learner-centered processes, outcomes including attitudes/skills/knowledge). Don situates education as support for the "road of life" journey and argues these criteria reflect community concerns better than standardized test results alone. Advocates supplementing PISA/PCAP with broader quality measures.
content_preview:
March 21, 2016




Dear Editor:	




A Quality Education




The road of life is a way of describing our journey between birth and death, and education provides help as we travel.  Help comes in many forms and from many people and its focus is on increasing and improving the knowledge, skills and attitudes needed to meet challenges along the way.  As a result, our quality of life will depend, to a large degree, on the quality of education that we experience.  




In 2000, UNICEF identified the characteristics of a quality education as one with:

Learners who are healthy

Environments that are healthy and safe

Content that is relevant

Processes that are learner centered

Outcomes that include attitudes, skills and knowledge




It seems to me that these are a good reflection of community concerns, lend themselves to large scale assessment, would give us a broader view of quality in our schools and be a welcome supplement the results of PISA, PCAP and school tests. 

Sincerely




Don Glendenning

A long-time student of education

Don explains that while PEI math test scores have risen, practical numeracy skills remain weak on the shop floor. He proposes a DACUM analysis to identify the 100+ math skills needed for everyday island life at a cost of $15,000, noting his prior success using this methodology at Holland College. The letter invites donations through the Community Foundation of PEI. This document showcases Don's continued professional engagement, his understanding of applied mathematics education, and his fundraising acumen in retirement.

Dear:

Math
on PEI






Although
PEI math scores on National and international tests have risen,
friends tell me that math has not improved on the shop floor; I’ve
been wondering why.






All
Islanders need math. they need to be able to measure, sort,
calculate, group and estimate numbers, space, time, distance, etc.

 This approach to math is called numeracy and it involves the
